pages.text: Caerorhachis bairdi comes from the Early Carboniferous, with fossils being found in the Limestone Coal Group, Scotland (United Kingdom). It is a small Stem-Tetrapod, growing up to 30 cm in length. With full fossil material, it has been noted that Caerorhachis may have lived a more different lifestyle to its ancestors, being more terrestrial, but still occasionally venturing into water streams for food.

The generic name derives from the Greek words 'kairos', to mean 'suitable'; and 'rhachis', to mean 'spine'. The specific name derives from the Latinised surname of Dr. Donal Baird, who prepared the first specimen and recognised its significance.
